repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Taunsa Barrage Emergency
            Rehabilitation and Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Taunsa Barrage Emergency
            Rehabilitation and Modernization Project for Pakistan were
            as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: a
            well-structured consultative process involving all
            stakeholders, particularly the beneficiaries, should precede
            project preparation. A communication strategy should be
            developed to keep constant liaison with all stakeholders for
            projects of this nature. This will minimize complaints that
            come forth during project implementation. The borrower
            should be adequately informed at all levels that the
            Bank's procedures need to be followed for all
            procurements. The contractors must build good relations with
            the local community to ensure smooth implementation.
            Detailed engineering design of Employer's site
            facilities to be constructed by the contractor and location
            of contractor's site facilities should be a part of the
            bidding documents to avoid variation orders later on and
            social disruption. A sound financial management, accounting
            and reporting system managed by qualified staff is a key
            element for a smooth implementation of the project.
            Consideration should be given to out-sourcing certain
            aspects of financial management to professional firms,
            instead of setting up in-house systems. Periodic review of
            Project activities by an independent Panel of Experts (POE)
            is an effective tool for taking corrective measures and
            ensuring quality.

12545079.trustfund: TF050819-BNWPP SPECIAL-STAFF AND ADMINISTRATION,TF050933-BNWPP-DAMS PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Taunsa Barrage Rehabilitation
            and Modernization Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the Taunsa
            Barrage Emergency Rehabilitation and Modernization Project
            are to take urgent steps to prevent the failure of the
            Taunsa Barrage, which provides irrigation for two million
            acres, in addition to drinking water to several million
            farmers in the rural areas of Southern Punjab; and to
            prepare for similar steps with respect to other existing
            barrages in Punjab. In view of potential environmental
            adversity during construction works, this environmental
            impact assessment provides mitigation measures in compliance
            with the Bank's operational directives on the
            environment, the project having been classified as category
            B. This category is justified, since environmental impacts
            will be localized over immediate project areas and
            agricultural lands will be avoided at the construction
            stage. Contractors shall comply with specific contract
            requirements and with the social framework agreement
            precautionary clauses. In addition, retrogression downstream
            and pulsating hydraulic jumps shall be in compliance with
            technically sound and economical designs of the secondary
            weir, as will all other aspects of construction, and/or
            engineering design. Construction wastes will be disposed of
            at selected sites, and is the responsibility of the
            contractor as defined in relevant contracts. Soil erosion
            will be controlled, and the terrain should stabilize
            accordingly. Oil spills, lubricants, and hazardous materials
            will be stored in covered tanks, to be disposed of per
            standard international regulations. Drainage systems will be
            regularly inspected to avoid any possible sedimentation or
            obstruction. Embankments or concrete walls will be installed
            around the construction perimeter to secure construction
            sites. Regular discharges and water flows will be regularly
            controlled to avoid potential surface and water
            contamination, while construction surfaces, and materials
            should be covered to avoid air pollution. To mitigate noise
            disturbances, working schedules will be limited to daytime
            working hours. Inspections will be conducted by wildlife,
            forest, and fisheries officials to ensure environmental
            protection of sites or enforce legislation as needed. The
            report also addresses social issues, including tribal
            issues, particularly on the uses of canals and aquatic life.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Taunsa Barrages Emergency
            Rehabilitation and Modernization Project : resettlement
            action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement action plan for the
            Taunsa Barrages Emergency Rehabilitation and Modernization
            Project for Pakistan comprises an introduction to the
            project, social survey of project affected persons, project
            effects, eligibility and entitlements, consultation and
            grievance mechanisms, institutional framework,
            implementation schedule, monitoring and evaluation, and
            resettlement/rehabilitation costs and budget. The residence
            of a squatter community on the left and right banks
            downstream of Taunsa Barrage was anticipated as a problem in
            that the contractor would be operating in the vicinity of
            the settlements. The Irrigation and Power Department shifted
            them to an alternate location. This shifting has resulted in
            some problems and issues related to resettlement and
            rehabilitation. This resettlement action plan's main
            objective is to develop a policy and compensation framework
            for resettling and rehabilitation of project affected
            persons by quantifying their losses and adopting appropriate
            mitigation measures for the adverse effects of displacement.
            A total of 157 households on the left and right banks will
            be affected by this project. Key effects of dislocation are
            displacement of the dwellings of 157 households, loss of
            income during transition, psychological distress due to
            dislocation, debt burden for house construction, and loss of
            communal amenities. Compensation for loss of housing
            structures and income interruption allowances are to be paid
            in cash to project affected individuals. Suggested
            mitigation measures also include community development
            schemes, arrangement of business investment schemes for
            males and females, and arrangement of business investment
            schemes for males and females, and arrangement of employment
            opportunities with the construction contractor.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Taunsa Barrage Emergency
            Rehabilitation and Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Taunsa Barrage
            Emergency Rehabilitation and Modernization Project for
            Pakistan are: (a) to take urgent steps to prevent the
            failure of the Taunsa Barrage which provides irrigation for
            two million acres and drinking water to several million
            farmers in the rural areas of Southern Punjab; and (b) to
            prepare for similar steps with respect to other existing
            barrages in Punjab. The objectives will be achieved through:
            (i) rehabilitating and strengthening the Taunsa Barrage and
            associated structures; (ii) renovation and modernization of
            gates, hoists and operating and control facilities; (iii)
            improving operation and maintenance capability; and (iv)
            rehabilitation design studies for other barrages in Punjab.
            The major benefits of the Project stem from securing
            irrigation of the cultivated lands in the command areas of
            over two million acres in the two canal commands of
            Muzaffargarh and Dera Ghazi Khan, and through the
            Taunsa-Panjnad Link Canal to supplement water supply to
            Panjnad Headworks canals. Other benefits from the
            rehabilitation of the barrage include: (a) long-term and
            effective functioning of the critical oil and gas pipelines,
            and telephone lines; and (b) ensuring continued availability
            of vital rail and road links of strategic importance between
            the Punjab and the Sindh and Balochistan provinces.

Pakistan - Taunsa Barrage Emergency
